Most Illustrious Sir

With the losses I suffered after the concordat I obtained on September 15, 1831, I was almost unable to precisely fulfill the obligations I had undertaken thereby, and now, due to the political movements that have taken place in the Province, I not only find myself entirely deprived of the ability to put into effect such duties, but also, if at this time I tried to sell the existing goods, besides not finding anyone who would demand them, they would be considered as having such diminished values that this would amount to a total loss, thus causing serious damage to my creditors and to myself in particular. In view of so many reasons, I dare to beg Your Excellency

God keep Your Excellency Pelotas, November 16, 1835. From Your Excellency Domingos Jos√© de Almeida.

Most Illustrious Sir. Examining the content of your letter of the 16th of the current month, I reply that, on my part, I agree to your proposal. Pelotas, November 24, 1835. Your very attentive worshipful servant Guilherme Rodrigo de Carvalho.

Most Illustrious Sir. [On the verso] City of Pelotas.

Answered.
